wikipedia_page.main:
Alfred Holland (29 January 1900 – 30 August 1936) was a Labour Party politician in England.
He was elected at the 1935 general election as Member of Parliament (MP) for Clay Cross, filling the seat held by Arthur Henderson until his death shortly before the election. Holland died of meningitis only 9 months after his election to the House of Commons, aged 36.

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the 1935 United Kingdom general election

response: *Alfred Holland (politician) (1900–1936), British Labour Party Member of Parliament 1935–1936
*Alfred Holland (bishop) (1927–2018), former Anglican Bishop of Newcastle in New South Wales, Australia

He was elected as the Member of Parliament (MP) for Clay Cross at a by-election in September 1936, filling the vacancy caused by the death of Alfred Holland at the age of 36. Like his predecessor, Ridley did not live until the next general election but died in January 1944 at 57. He was survived by his wife, Ethel, and his children, Philip and Betty.

The Clay Cross by-election of 1936 was held on 5 November 1936.  The by-election was held due to the death of the incumbent Labour MP, Alfred Holland.  It was retained by the Labour candidate George Ridley.
